title: The Trump Admin's Signal Clone Was Hacked

rawLines.text: In today's world, data breaches happen
all the time, and even the most secure
companies can't always protect their
employees personal information from
ending up in the wrong hands. That's
where Delete Me comes in. Delete Me is a
service that removes your employees
sensitive information from hundreds of
data broker websites, sites where
hackers can find phone numbers and
emails within seconds. Rachel Tobach,
CEO of SocialProof Security, says
attackers use this data to target
employees with fishing messages and AI
powered phone scams. But delete me makes
it harder for these bad actors by
scrubbing your employees details
regularly. It's simple. Attackers are
lazy. If it's too hard to find contact
info, they'll move on to easier targets.
Delete Me takes care of this for you,
doing the heavy lifting so you don't
have to. And over time, they keep
removing the information so it stays
down, protecting your team from constant
exposure. If your business has a social
presence or deals with clients, you need
Delete Me. Visit
deleteme.com/44 media and start
safeguarding your team's information
today. That's
deleteme.com/44 media.
Hello and welcome to the 404 media
podcast where we bring you unparalleled

IRL. 404 media is a journalist founded

respond to their best comments. Gain
access to that content at

Um, this is a collaboration between

how would you describe Mike Ali other

the site? Uh, I would say Michael Lee is
a very accomplished technologist and

the Intercept uh and working with a lot
of hacks and leaked data and that sort
of thing. And that's where I first knew
about his work. Uh and then he actually
published a book which is very very
useful. I'm actually going to bring it
up now. The art of analyzing hacked
data, hacked and leaked data. And I mean
it's phenomenal. I need to go back and
work through more of it. But it provides
journalists like all of these different
scripts and guides on how to analyze
leaked information. So he's very very
experienced in this world. you know, in
the same way we are. We're very
experienced in verifying data, but he
brings a much more um technical frame of
mind to all, you know, in technical
expertise for sure. Yeah. Uh was really
nice working with him. Hopefully we can
have him on the pod at some point. Uh,
so last week you discovered via an image
that Reuters took that the Trump admin
was using a signal clone to communicate
and this was made by a company called
Tele. What is Tele message and how do we

into the photo and I think some other
people did on Blue Sky and they were
like, "Oh, look, they're using Signal."
When I looked it, I was like, "Huh,
there's something odd about that and it
said something like verify TM signal
pin." Uh, and then that's how we
determined it was actually a different
version of signal. And what this is, at
least I'll do it, I'll explain in the
way that Tele message explains it, which
is that this is an ordinary version of
Signal, a complete copy, except it does
one thing, which is archive your
messages, right? And they say they do
that securely. And the idea is that well
if you're a government agency you need
to keep copies of messages for
recordeping purposes for legal reasons
as well and maybe if you work in a
regulated industry like finance or
something cryptocurrency that sort of
thing you probably need to keep records
uh of messages as well you know under
SEC regulations and that sort of thing.
So the idea is that it provides a secure
way to chat while also meeting those
archiving requirements. Yeah. So we were
already having kind of a busy weekend,
but then this blew up on Sunday. What
happened on Sunday? Yeah, on Sunday, uh
Micah reached out to us. Um, and then me
and you spoke about this and basically
what had happened was a hacker had
managed to breach
tele sort of way and we didn't have all
of the specifics immediately that only

immediately clear from seeing the

And as the headline says, and just like
really to put a pin on it, the app that

um uh changed our weekend plans. Yeah.
So you talked to this hacker. What are

Yeah. So they told me how they did it.

Yeah, they said it was very very quick.

highly concerning. Um, Jason, you

Um,
notably did some stuff with Vice back

Democratic staffer on the Senate side.

uh quote, did not sign the opposition

Um, you know, there's some typos in

essentially this was them talking about

now for this company, uh, that is had a

very
sensitive. Uh so what are the

We're not like, you know, unencrypting

Well, I think that that doesn't really

so that's, you know, obviously the first

maybe the final thing is that is that um

it's what makes the story really scary.

Um, it's really really hard because I

Let's say that the service um that's

letting the plain text of the signal

inherently there is a problem here.
Absolutely. Yeah. I think I mean you you

very clear,
but like this is what a hacker was able

Um, just on that monumental [ __ ] idea,
